metadata.ttm:title: General Importance
metadata.ttm:desc: An Authorized Negotiator is an individual designated to work on a GSA Contract, and, if given the authority to sign, can bind his or her Company to purchasing agreements with the federal government. This video explains the role of an Authorized Negotiator, as well as the steps required to be sure Authorized Negotiators maintain the access to GSA systems they require.

div.p: Whether you are a long time participant or are
new to the GSA Schedules program, you may think you
have an understanding of what an "Authorized
Negotiator's" role on the contract actually entails.
As the name implies, an Authorized Negotiator is
someone who a company designates as being
authorized to negotiate and bind the company to
any changes or updates to its GSA contract.
If a particular employee of your company is NOT
listed as an Authorized Negotiator on your
contract, he or she will not be able to prepare or
sign off on modifications to your GSA contract.
In fact, he or she will not even be able to access
the eOffer/eMods system!
Even further, just because a person is listed as an
Authorized Negotiator on a contract doesn't
necessarily mean that he or she can submit a
modification to GSA for approval.
There are two types of Authorized Negotiators:
Those with signing authority and those
without.
Let's first talk about those Authorized
Negotiators without signing authority and why
this particular role was introduced to eOffer/eMod.
Preparing an offer for a GSA Schedule is a fairly
intensive process.
It requires companies to gather a lot of
documentation and do a lot of writing about their
company history, the types of goods and services they
offer, and a wealth of other information.
Realizing the level of effort necessary to
prepare a responsive offer, many companies
began relying on services of third parties to help
complete their GSA Schedule proposals.
There needed to be a mechanism in place,
however, that would allow these third parties to
access the eOffer/eMod system and enter
information, but be prevented from submitting
any offers or modifications that would
bind the company.
This is where "Authorized Negotiators Without
Signing Authority" come in to the picture.
Users with this role - whether they are your own
employees or those of a third party consulting
company - can still access the system and help work
on contract offers and modifications.
They can submit this information, but they
cannot actually sign the final product.
By separating those users without signing authority
from those with such authority, the ability to
sign and submit contract documents can be retained
with a trusted company employee.
With all of this in mind, the importance of
maintaining accurate authorized negotiator
information cannot be overstated.
As an example, imagine for a moment that a wonderful
new opportunity comes up for which you need to add
new products to your contract.
This opportunity could be worth a LOT of money and
you only have a short time to take advantage of it.
All of a sudden, you remember your GSA
training.
You can't just add the new products to your contract.
You need to have an Authorized Negotiator with
signing authority actually sign the modification.
Realizing this, you think of Susan Sicklee, the
individual who has been designated as your
company's authorized negotiator.
Unfortunately, she has been out all week with the
flu.
"No problem," you think to yourself.
"I remember that Robert Retiree was an authorized
negotiator on the contract as well.
I even think he helped write the proposal.
He can take care of this...."
Then.
A moment of panic.
Robert retired from the company last month.
He's still listed on the contract and you never
assigned anyone else to serve in his place.
Finally, you recall having asked your intern Nathan
Nosign to assist in the preparation of your
schedule offer.
Nathan is in the office today, but, while he was
responsible for helping to prepare your offer and is
an Authorized Negotiator on the contract, he was
not registered as having the necessary signing
privileges to bind the company to modifications
with GSA.
With no Authorization Negotiator with signing
privileges available, you cannot execute the
modification and will not be able to take advantage
of the new contract opportunity.
This scenario, while purely hypothetical,
illustrates some of the problems that contractors
run in to when they don't keep their Authorized
Negotiator information up to date.
Let's take a look at how this problem could be
avoided as well as some of the steps GSA has taken to
make dealing with Authorized Negotiator
information easier for you, the GSA Schedule
contractor.
First, let's acknowledge the positive steps that
were taken.
When you submitted your offer, you took note of
GSA's recommendation that you assign at least two
negotiators to a contract.
In fact, you went above and beyond and assigned
three people: Susan Sicklee and Robert Retiree
who are both Authorized Negotiators with signing
privileges, and Nathan Nosign, who is an
Authorized Negotiator but does not have the
authority to sign off on modifications.
Instances where someone like Susan who may be out
sick are not uncommon.
This is why assigning a second Negotiator with
signing authority is of extreme importance.
In addition, vendors often get the help of people
like Nathan to prepare offers and monitor their
schedule but do not want these people to sign off
on any changes to the contract.
The real break down here centers on the lack of
monitoring of Authorized Negotiator information.
It is recommended that, at a minimum, you review your
Authorized Negotiator information each month to
ensure that the information is current.
You should also be sure that the digital
certificates of your negotiators are not about
to expire.
In the above scenario, it would have been easy to
see that Robert Retiree has departed from the
company leaving Susan Sicklee as the only
Authorized Negotiator with signing authority on the
contract.
So what steps should you take to be sure that this
does not happen to you?
First, make sure that at least two Authorized
Negotiators are included on the contract at all
times.
Second, review all Authorized Negotiator
information each month to ensure that their
information remains current and that their
digital certificates are not set to expire.
Third, even if you have multiple negotiators
assigned to the contract, be sure to check on their
signing privileges.
Users without the ability to sign modifications
cannot execute agreements with GSA.
Remember these steps during the administration
of your contract and you should be fine.
Do note that there are additional issues that may
arise when dealing with Digital Certificates and
when an Authorized Negotiator's information
does not match that which is present on an
individual's cert.
Videos covering these topics are available from
the eOffer/eMod home page.
If you have any additional questions, please consult
the eOffer/eMod User Guide or feel free to contact us
by e-mail eoffer@gsa.gov.
Thank you for your continued support of the
General Services Administration.
